questions.question: What is the significance of the linker length in the formation of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers?
questions.answer: The length variation of the DNx linker (x = 1–10) influences the formation of diverse 1D to 3D coordination polymers. Specifically, with DNx (x = 1–6), simple CPs are observed. At x = 7, the system switches to form unprecedented 3D supramolecular CPs. Longer linkers (DN8–10) lead to larger nano-sized supramolecular nodes serving as containers for host molecules. The flexibility of the system and the adjustable lengths of the linkers are crucial for this transition.

questions.question: What role does the weakly coordinating anion SbF6@ play in the self-assembly of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers?
questions.answer: The weakly coordinating anion SbF6@, along with the five-fold symmetric building block pentaphosphaferrocene [Cp*Fe(h5-P5)] (A), and Ag+, facilitates the formation of coordination sites on the Ag ion for N-donor linkers. This enables the self-assembly of nano-sized organometallic Ag-based spherical aggregates, ready for host–guest interactions, into 3D supramolecular coordination polymers.

questions.question: How does the formation of simple CPs differ from the formation of 3D supramolecular CPs based on the length of DNx?
questions.answer: Simple CPs are formed with DNx (x = 1–6), while the formation of 3D supramolecular CPs occurs at x = 7 and above. The transition to 3D supramolecular CPs is attributed to the flexibility and adjustable lengths of the DNx linkers, which enable the formation of larger nano-sized supramolecular nodes that can serve as containers for host molecules.

questions.question: What experimental techniques were used to characterize the 3D supramolecular coordination polymers?
questions.answer: The 3D supramolecular coordination polymers were characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction, NMR spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, IR spectra, ESI MS spectra, 31P MAS NMR measurement, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

questions.question: What is the structural feature of the 56-vertex polycationic host–guest assembly (SbF6)@[(A)9Ag11]11+?
questions.answer: The 56-vertex polycationic host–guest assembly (SbF6)@[(A)9Ag11]11+ is a unique spherical host scaffold that acts as a node in a 3D supramolecular coordination polymer. It is characterized by its ability to encapsulate an SbF6@ counter-anion within its structure, demonstrating the assembly's capability for host–guest chemistry.

questions.question: What is the observed effect of cooling on the crystallographic disorder in the structures of the supramolecular CPs?
questions.answer: Cooling to temperatures as low as 10–30 K leads to the additional non-uniform shortening of the dinitrile units but does not eliminate the static nature of the crystallographic disorder in the supramolecular CPs. The guest molecules, the scaffold, linkers, and SbF6@ anions remain positionally disordered even at these low temperatures.

questions.question: True or False: The formation of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers is influenced by the delivery of a special template molecule.
questions.answer: False. The ability of the three-component system to self-assemble into spherical polyphosphorus supramolecules over simple polymers occurs in the absence of additional stimuli. The templating ion (SbF6@ in 7 a) or a molecule (A in 8–10 a) are always present in the system and therefore cannot be the driving force behind the unusual behavior in self-assembly.

questions.question: True or False: The 3D supramolecular CPs show decomposition when stored in a glovebox.
questions.answer: False. The 3D supramolecular CPs do not show decomposition when stored in a glovebox and can be kept under mother liquor solution for six months or longer. They only degrade upon exposure to air or changes in the mother liquor solution composition.

questions.question: What is the impact of the DNx linker folding on the formation of 3D supramolecular CPs?
questions.answer: The folding of the DNx linkers impacts the effective lengths of the linkers and their ability to accommodate SbF6@ counter-anions that compensate the charge of polycationic nodes in the outer sphere. The folding ensures reasonable van der Waals contacts between the spheres and influences the connectivity of the network, with a tendency to lower connectivity observed with the elongation of the DNx linker.

questions.question: True or False: The TEM studies of compound 8 showed well-defined individual spherical nodes.
questions.answer: False. The TEM studies of compound 8 showed smaller and larger aggregates rather than well-defined individual spherical nodes. The smallest aggregates have mean diameters larger than the maximal dimension of the individual spherical node, indicating aggregation rather than isolated nodes.
